verses.verse: ((2 Job declareth the mighty power of God, and that man’s righteousness is nothing.) ) Then Job answered, and said,

I know verily that it is so: for how should man compared unto God, be (Job here answereth to that point of Eliphaz and Bildad’s oration, touching the justice of God, and his innocency, confessing God to be infinite in justice, and man to be nothing in respect.) justified?
If he would dispute with him, he could not answer him one thing of (Of a thousand things, which God could lay to his charge, man cannot answer him one.) thousand.
He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath been fierce against him, and hath prospered?
He removeth the mountains, and they feel not when he overthroweth them in his wrath.

He (He declareth what is the infirmity of man, by the mighty and incomprehensible power that is in God, showing what he could do if he would set forth his power.) removeth the earth out of her place, that the pillars thereof do shake.
He commandeth the Sun, and it riseth not: he closeth up the stars, as under a signet.
He himself alone spreadeth out the heavens, and walketh upon the height of the Sea.

He maketh the stars (These are the names of certain stars whereby he meaneth that all stars both known and unknown are at his appointment.) Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the climates of the South.
He doeth great things, and unsearchable: yea, marvelous things without number.

Lo, when he goeth (I am not able to comprehend his works, which are common and daily before my eyes, much less in those things, which are hid and secret.) by me, I see him not: and when he passeth by, I perceive him not:

Behold, when he taketh a prey, (He showeth that when God doth execute his power, he doeth it justly, forasmuch as none can control him.) who can make him to restore it? who shall say unto him, What doest thou?

God (God will not be appeased for ought that man can say for himself for his justification.) will not withdraw his anger, and the most mighty helpers (That is, all the reasons that men can lay to approve their cause.) do stoop under him.

How much less shall I answer him? or how should I find out (How should I be able to answer him by eloquence? whereby he noteth his friends, that albeit they were eloquent in talk, yet they felt not in heart, that which they spake.) my words with him?

For though I were just, yet could I (Meaning, in his own opinion, signifying, that man will sometimes flatter himself to be righteous, which before God is abomination.) not answer, but I would make supplication to my Judge.
If I (While I am in my pangs, I cannot but burst forth into many inconveniences, although I know still that God is just.) cry, and he answer me, yet would I not believe, that he heard my voice.

For he destroyeth me with a tempest, and woundeth me (I am not able to feel my sins so great, as I feel the weight of his plagues; and this he speaketh to condemn his dullness, and to justify God.) without cause.
He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
If we speak of strength, behold, he is (After he hath accused his own weakness, he continueth to justify God and his power.) strong: if we speak of judgment, who shall bring me in to plead?

If I should justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: (If I would stand in mine own defense, yet God hath just cause to condemn me, if he examine mine heart and conscience.) if I would be perfect, he shall judge me wicked.
Though I were perfect, yet I know not my soul: therefore abhor I my life.

This is one point: therefore I said, He destroyeth the (If God punish according to his justice, he will destroy as well them, that are counted perfect as them that are wicked.) perfect and the wicked.

If the scourge should suddenly (To wit, the wicked.) slay, should God (This is spoken according to our apprehension, as though he would say, If God destroy but the wicked, as Job 5:3, why should he suffer the innocent to be so long tormented by them?) laugh at the punishment of the innocent?
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: (That they cannot see to do justice.) he covereth the faces of the judges thereof: if not, where (That can show the contrary?) is he? or who is he?
My days have been more swift than a post: they have fled, and have seen no good thing.
They are passed as with the most swift ships, and as the Eagle that flieth to the prey.

If (I think not to fall into these afflictions, but my sorrows bring me to these manifold infirmities, and my conscience condemneth me.) I say, I will forget my complaint, I will cease from my wrath, and comfort me,
Then I am afraid of all my sorrows, knowing that thou wilt not judge me innocent.
If I be wicked, why (Why doth not God destroy me at once? thus he speaketh according to the infirmity of the flesh.) labor I thus in vain?
If I wash (Though I seem never so pure in mine own eyes, yet all is but corruption before God.) myself with snow water, and purge mine hands most clean,
Yet shalt thou plunge me in the pit, and mine own (Whatsoever I would use to cover my filthiness with, shall disclose me so much more.) clothes shall make me filthy.
For he is not a man as I am, that I should answer him, if we come together to judgment.
Neither is there any umpire (Which might make an accord between God and me, speaking of impatience, and yet confessing God to be just in punishing him.) that might lay his hand upon us both.
Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear astonish me:
Then will I speak, and fear him not: (Signifying that God’s judgments keep him in awe.) but because I am not so, I hold me still.
